intro: Chrysopsis viscida var. cinerascens, commonly known as the cinerascens chrysopsis, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly in regions of Argentina and Chile. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and foliage that often features a silvery or grayish hue. The plant typically grows in rocky or dry environments, exhibiting a low, spreading growth habit. Its leaves are often covered in fine, soft hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance and aiding in water retention. The flowers, which bloom in the spring, are yellow and can be found in clusters, making it an attractive addition to gardens in suitable climates.
